So I think you can break NBs into two groups. There are non-dysphoric NBs, who are just gender non-conforming cis people who seem to think that quirky presentation = different gender. This group is absolutely influenced by online discourse in their decision making, and they tend to be pretty radical. These people aren #8217;t trans, and often just present like their birth sex apart from maybe one difference (such as a male wearing nail polish and then saying he is NB). Often times, this group can also consist of homosexual or bisexual people as well, and because they don #8217;t fit their set gender norms they are told they #8217;re a different gender, when really they #8217;re not. This is the passive homophobia and biphobia that you find in a lot of NB spaces and discourse, unfortunately. Then there are the dysphoric NBs, or the actual trans people who identify as NB. This is a much smaller group, and from my conversations with them they get pretty pissed off about how the non-dysphoric crowd appropriate their identity. They #8217;re trans, and should be respected. However, I #8217;ll say that I #8217;m not NB and don #8217;t understand NB dysphoria. From my view, it seems to be less of a real third gender option, and more of a misunderstanding of certain ways dysphoria works, or from confused and sort of iffy perspectives on what it is to actually be a man or woman. A trans woman having discomfort presenting feminine, or not having bottom dysphoria, might think (or be told, as was my case) that she is NB, when really she just doesn #8217;t have bottom dysphoria and might not enjoy feminine clothing or might not yet be comfortable enough with herself to wear it without feeling awkward. Either way though, whether my theories as to why someone would identify as NB are right or not, if they #8217;re dysphoric then they #8217;re trans and I will respect them.

Lol it #8217;s not my job to explain everything I agree and disagree with her on, and that wasn #8217;t the point of this post at all. The point was that anyone who reads her essay with honest intent will probably find some things they agree with her on, some they disagree with her on, and some things that they #8217;re neutral or unsure of, and that there is a conversation to be had there rather than a need to shut down conversation because you disagree with a percentage of it. Condemn that percentage, whatever that percentage is, and have a conversation about it. Figure out what is correct and what isn #8217;t. Condemn the entire person and attempt to shut down debate and you only strengthen their resolve and prove nothing other than your own intellectual fragility. What I do and do not agree with her on is irrelevant. The fact that agreeing with her on anything at all is a problem because she has some bad views is the issue here. If you #8217;re so eager, I #8217;ll give one example of something that she has said that I would put into the grey area of agreeing and disagreeing. She has stated that gay kids are being pushed to transition when they #8217;re actually just gay, not trans. I think she probably thinks it #8217;s a bigger issue than it is, and can sometimes edge towards saying, though not literally saying, #8220;trans people are just confused gay people with internalized homophobia #8221;. That #8217;s a bad take, *if* that #8217;s her intent. However, I know a shit ton of gay people who thought they were trans because of their nonconformity, and they had this false idea further pushed on them and reinforced by those around them. It caused them incredible confusion and pain, some even starting transitioning and now absolutely regretting it. Some of these people, when they #8220;detransitioned #8221; (if they did) were attacked by who they thought were their friends. They were even called homophobic slurs. I #8217;ve seen this behavior. It #8217;s a problem in the trans community, and I agree with her on that, though obviously I don #8217;t think that #8217;s all or even most trans people. Something I do agree with her on is the sexual pushing that is exhibited in trans spaces. I can #8217;t tell you how often I #8217;ve seen people say it #8217;s transphobic to not sleep with them because of their genitals, and I #8217;ve often seen this turn into using homophobic and sexist slurs against people for the crime of being gay and having a genital preference. She has spoken against this attempted erasure you see in trans spaces, and I agree with her on that. It #8217;s a thing, and it happens more often than you #8217;d think. An example of something I disagree with her on is her outright defense of terfs who have done terrible shit. It #8217;s disgusting, and she knows what they did and she condones it. I disagree with that stance. I also disagree with her view of trans men, who she has stated she views as women. That #8217;s fucked up, I disagree. The thing is, there are conversations to be had on all those points, and without conversation nobody is going to change or grow. You #8217;re not going to scare or cancel the bad ideas away, you #8217;re just going to push them into dark corners where they will fester without anyone noticing, and they #8217;ll erupt out again worse than before. Like I #8217;ve said before, I #8217;ve never canceled someone into being accepting of my transition. I #8217;ve talked with them about it and over time they grew. Anyway, I #8217;m done with the witch hunt and having to explain what I do and do not agree with her on. That #8217;s not the point, and it #8217;s nobody #8217;s business. So take from this what you will, and have a good one #128075;

I #8217;m not even sure how to start getting better and dismantling the walls. I #8217;ve tried for 6 years now with no luck at all. I don #8217;t know what to do about them, they feel impenetrable :( I think the problem I have with therapy is that I have so so much I want to say, but if I try to say the words my mouth refuses to open. I can #8217;t do it. The more I push the harder it gets, until I #8217;m forced to either tiptoe around the issue or pretend that everything is fine and that I don #8217;t have a reason to be there. It feels like the issue is my own inability to communicate rather than their inability to try and reach me. There #8217;s a lyric of a song I like that goes #8220;words are just complicated air flow #8221;. I think my issue is that when the walls come up, that airflow doesn #8217;t happen. I can try to form the words as hard as I want, but I can #8217;t get the air to move, if that makes sense.

Usually I just stop being able to even say anything. I just end up going in circles until I shut up :( Maybe I need better therapists, idk. It #8217;s kinda hard to find good therapists. I can #8217;t just like call up a single local expert, ya know? I #8217;m stuck working with my medical system and insurance to find someone, and they all tend to take this sort of generalized approach that just feels like a script. They #8217;re all obnoxiously gentle too, which is like completely unhelpful because I *might* be able to force out a word or two if I #8217;m being pushed, but nobody is pushing, and my muscles would sooner shut down than let me say anything of my own volition.

I think that makes some sense, though I honestly feel so defeated at this point that I feel skeptical. It just seems like I retry therapy every 6-12 months and I never end up getting used to how they talk to me. Idk if I would be able to without seeing them for years and years, but I always get defeated and stop because it #8217;s hard to see someone once a week for 6 months and make zero progress. I joked with a friend recently that I need a #8220;daddy therapist #8221; lol, but I think there might be some truth to that. I feel like I need someone who is going to establish expectations and isn #8217;t going to allow me to flounder awkwardly for months on end, but I don #8217;t know if I can ever find that or if that would ultimately be helpful either #129335; #127996; #8205; #9792; #65039; Idk, I appreciate your help though. Maybe after the pandemic is over I could give therapy a try again. I just wish their were resources I could use on my own without therapy at the moment, but idk maybe feeling more comfortable quietly trying to deal with this on my own is just another symptom of my problem with opening up to others.

I used to be the director of a food pantry and let me tell you, this shit is so much more common than you #8217;d think. The amount of food pyramids I had to make to fit all our unstackable cans was a nightmare, and the cleanup after the pyramid of cans inevitably fell over was even worse lol

I would do that too, but it made it a hassle because sometimes for space reasons we had to stack, say, various canned fruits all next to each other. Canned pineapple goes faster than canned peaches, so when the top row of canned pineapple was finished people had to try and lift the cardboard that still had cans on top of it to get the the pineapple below. Once all that is gone, the balance is messed up and the top row tends to all fall. Sure, I suppose we could have sliced single-row sized sheets of cardboard, but when you #8217;re dealing with the volume we were and the number of people coming and going, we didn #8217;t have time for that.

I think a fundamental difference with trans people vs other groups is that not wanting to be an outside group is a central component of transition. I have no desire to publicly identify myself as a trans woman and to fight for trans rights as part of an organized movement. Transition amounted to a 5 year medical treatment that I finished. I live in the world as a woman now, and so I #8217;ve pretty much left the whole trans part of my life in the past at this point. I can see how it might be different for those who don #8217;t pass, but like idk for those of us that have ok transitions organizing around a movement and controlling a narrative is so far out of the picture when it comes to where I want my life to go. It feels selfish of me, but idk access to hormones, srs, therapies, legal gender changes, etc didn #8217;t come as a result from nationwide protests and some controlled narrative, they came as a result of us keeping to ourselves letting the medical professionals do their job. Maybe it #8217;s too late to go back to that now, maybe the radicals took that away from is forever, but idk I just feel done. I think maybe the next generation of trans people who have to deal with the inevitable backlash against the current ideology will have to fight to re-establish our legitimacy, but as selfish as it might be I just don #8217;t see that as my fight. At least not publicly. I voice my concern online anonymously, but irl I don #8217;t want anything to do with it. I #8217;m not outing myself when I #8217;ve come this far. Anyway sorry for the rambling I #8217;m stoned rn lol, but I hope that made sense

BDSM isn #8217;t inherently abusive, but can easily be if not negotiated properly, if not 125% consensual, if the people engaging in it are inexperienced, etc. The real worry when it comes to BDSM and abuse is that people can use it to excuse their own abusive behavior or, on the other end of the spectrum, it can make a victim feel unsure of whether or not what they are experiencing is in fact abuse. To make it absolutely clear: unless everything that happens was safe and specifically negotiated before hand in a sober and consensual way, and unless consent was not revoked but was able to comfortably be revoked at any point without fear, it is abuse.

Nobody here is saying #8220;trannies gotta get tf out of the LGB and stfu #8221;. When people here say that we shouldn #8217;t be part of LGBT, they #8217;re making the distinction that we are different from a sexuality minority. We #8217;re really a mental health minority, and maybe it would be better if we were considered as such rather than grouped in with the sexuality fight. All the other shit you said here I agree with though it #8217;s definitely dumb the way the sub is shifting. I #8217;m also sick of the encroaching tucute ideology. But like I don #8217;t think that saying #8220;we as a mental health minority aren #8217;t the same as a sexuality minority and maybe it doesn #8217;t serve our best interest to be considered a part of one #8221; is part of the problem. Pretty solid based truscum opinion actually.

Oh yeah no I fully understand the rationale behind having the two movements together. I was only clarifying that nobody here is supporting the #8220;drop the T #8221; movement as it stands, and that accusing people who think maybe we should separate ourselves because we are different of transphobia simply because a different group of transphobic people want us gone is disingenuous framing. It #8217;s fine to disagree with the desire to separate ourselves. I #8217;m personally torn on it, but framing it in a reactionary or disingenuous way isn #8217;t helping anything, and the fact that I get downvotes for clarifying a position that I don #8217;t even have a set opinion on is stupid #128526; #9996; #65039;

Saying people on this sub are #8220;supporting the #8216;drop the T #8217; movement #8221; and that #8220;that #8217;s fucking stupid as hell and quite honestly transphobic #8221; is framing what people are saying in a disingenuous manner. The #8220;drop the T #8221; movement is *not* the same as someone saying that a mental health minority isn #8217;t the same as a sexual minority and might have different goals and needs. They #8217;re not even close, and the latter isn #8217;t #8220;quite honestly transphobic #8221;. Nobody is supporting the transphobia that comes with #8220;drop the T #8221;, and *framing* what they are saying in that light is disingenuous.

It #8217;s almost like context and nuance are important. They #8217;re saying #8220;I don #8217;t think we belong here, and this is why #8221;. They are *not* saying what the Drop The movement is saying, and just because you can remove all context and nuance and then paint both positions as #8220;look, now the T is no longer with the LGB #8221; doesn #8217;t mean they #8217;re the same. 23f here and I understand how you feel, but try not to hate yourself for it. Relapse happens. Recovery is not linear, and a relapse doesn #8217;t make you a bad person or take away the four years you stopped. I mean four years is absolutely wild! You should be so proud of that! I couldn #8217;t manage more than two. You are so so strong. I understand how relapse is comforting, and it might not be something you want to give up right away. That #8217;s *okay*. You #8217;re in a tough spot right now, and you went to something you know and are familiar with. That #8217;s only natural, and it #8217;s only natural to want to hang on to that for a while. When you #8217;re ready, recovery will be there waiting for you again, and you #8217;ll be back on track before you know it. Try not to be too hard on yourself. You #8217;re strong and your soul is beautiful and you deserve the best. Take care of yourself, and if you ever need someone my dms are always open #10084; #65039;

We don #8217;t call straight people normal, we call them heterosexual. These are, more or less, academic terms. You wouldn #8217;t publish a paper #8220;Comparing Homeless Rates in Homosexual and Normal Children #8221;, you #8217;d publish #8220;Comparing Homeless Rates in Homosexual and Heterosexual Children #8221;. That #8217;s not to say I disagree and don #8217;t think transition is abnormal. It absolutely is. I #8217;m trans myself, what I go through and what I #8217;ve done to survive is not normal. But #8220;normal #8221; isn #8217;t a useful word because it #8217;s contextual. The definition of normal changes all the time, and what makes someone normal one day might not the next. The definitions of cis and trans are pretty solid, and so they #8217;re useful. It #8217;s important to define our terms

It #8217;s actually more helpful than you #8217;d think! Provides a sort of universality to scientific language. I work high up in the US healthcare field from a more administrative standpoint, and something like this won #8217;t make progress. Without a federal bill requiring it, which is pretty much impossible at the current moment given that things that are far less controversial and are considered higher priority aren #8217;t being done, you would have to individually petition each and every insurance provider in the country. Even if it did become law, these providers all have top notch legal teams. Each and every one of them would fight it in court, and they would win. The only solution that would possibly result in SRS being covered universally would be a universal healthcare program, which to be honest has a far greater likelihood of ever coming to fruition than the likelihood of finding success by petitioning each and every insurance company in the country or fighting hundreds of losing battles in court. I don #8217;t want to be a downer, but petitions like this aren #8217;t the answer. Calling your elected representatives to demand healthcare rights and volunteering to canvass and phone bank for candidates who fight for those rights is the answer. Petitions feel good, but they don #8217;t make this kind of change.

The definition of bisexual that bisexuals themselves have always used since the beginning of the community has been attraction regardless of gender. Pansexuals stole that definition and then redefined bisexual to mean something it doesn #8217;t. Specifically, they took all the stereotypes that historically had been deemed as biphobic and they grouped all of those in with #8220;bisexual #8221; (obsession with genitals, transphobic, etc) and they took the actual definition, #8220;attraction regardless of gender #8221; and renamed it. That is 1) redefining the bisexual community for us to paint us in a negative light, 2) perpetuating harmful bisexual stereotypes, and 3) erasure of bisexual history and identity.

I #8217;ve had some sh urges most of my life. Even going back to like being in early elementary school. I don #8217;t know why or where they came from. Maybe it was my abusive dad or the fact that I was so coddled by my mom that I didn #8217;t really ever get hurt unless I did it to myself. I remember I stuck my finger in a metal fan once when I was probably 5 because I wanted to know what it felt like, and then at maybe 7 or 8 I purposefully stepped on a humidifier because I wanted to burn the bottom of my foot. I had urges to burn myself on and off the rest of my childhood until about 18, but never really acted on them. I don #8217;t really consider those things the start of my self harm necessarily, because I didn #8217;t really understand what I was doing. I thought I was a freak for wanting to hurt myself, but like I didn #8217;t really understand why I wanted it. The first time I actively self harmed by like actually knowing why I wanted to do it was when I was 21 after a breakup with an abusive ex. That relationship left me so fucked up and confused and just empty feeling, and suddenly I was overcome with the urge to cut myself, so I did. Ended up in treatment shortly after that for my ED and we addressed the SH there as well a bit, and I was able to go clean for two years more or less (less clean with the ED, but like in active recovery). Now I #8217;m 23 and Covid and depression threw me for a loop, and I #8217;ve been struggling with increasingly escalating sh since July. Officially 7 days clean though as of like one minute ago!
